question_stem: The displacement, \(s\) metres, of a particle from a fixed point O at time \(t\) seconds is given by \(s = 4t^{\frac{3}{2}} + \frac{18}{t^{\frac{1}{2}}}\), where \(t > 0\).

parts.question_text: Find the exact value of the velocity of the particle when \(t = 9\).
parts.solution_text:
The velocity, \(v\), is the rate of change of displacement with respect to time, i.e., \(v = \frac{ds}{dt}\).

First, we differentiate \(s\) with respect to \(t\):

\(\frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(4t^{\frac{3}{2}}) + \frac{d}{dt}(18t^{-\frac{1}{2}})\)
\(\frac{ds}{dt} = 4 \times \frac{3}{2}t^{\frac{1}{2}} + 18 \times -\frac{1}{2}t^{-\frac{3}{2}}\)
\(\frac{ds}{dt} = 6t^{\frac{1}{2}} - 9t^{-\frac{3}{2}}\)
\(\frac{ds}{dt} = 6\sqrt{t} - \frac{9}{\sqrt{t^3}}\)

When \(t = 9\):

\(v = \frac{ds}{dt} = 6\sqrt{9} - \frac{9}{\sqrt{9^3}} = 6 \times 3 - \frac{9}{\sqrt{729}} = 18 - \frac{9}{27} = 18 - \frac{1}{3} = \frac{54 - 1}{3} = \frac{53}{3}\) m/s.
